population_specificity: Patients with prediabetes (n=145) and type 2 diabetes (n=196) in a Chinese population.
effective_dosage: HIIT: twelve 1-min bouts at 90% maximal aerobic capacity (1-min recovery); MICT: 20 min at 65% maximal aerobic capacity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the chronic effects of High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) on aerobic, anaerobic, and anthropometric outcomes in combat sports athletes.
results_summary: HIIT improved maximum oxygen uptake and anaerobic power in combat sport athletes, with minor effects on body composition. Aerobic capacity increased significantly, while anaerobic peak power improved notably in grappling athletes but not striking athletes.
population_specificity: Combat sports athletes (e.g., judo, taekwondo, boxing, wrestling).
effective_dosage: Not specified (varied protocols: HIIT, RST, SIT).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and sustainability of a high-frequency HIIT shock microcycle as an alternative periodization strategy for enhancing endurance performance in athletes.
results_summary: The study found that HIIT shock microcycles are sustainable and effective for improving intermittent and continuous running/cycling performance in athletes, with mitochondria biogenesis identified as a key physiological adaptation.
population_specificity: Athletes
effective_dosage: Multiple microcycles (7-10 days long) with 2-3 HIIT sessions each

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the influence of different volumes and intensities of aerobic exercise, including High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT), on cardiac autonomic function and the role of ADRB2 variants in overweight/obese individuals.
results_summary: 4-HIIT and moderate continuous training (MCT) showed positive outcomes for most variables, while 1-HIIT improved only systolic blood pressure and SD2 index. ADRB2 variants interacted with exercise to influence autonomic function, with specific genotype groups showing improvements in HRV indices.
population_specificity: Overweight/obese, physically inactive adults (n=70).
effective_dosage: 1-HIIT (1×4 min at 85-95%HR peak, 3×/week), 4-HIIT (4×4 min at 85-95%HR peak with 3 min recovery at 50-70%HR peak, 3×/week), MCT (30 min at 60-70%HR peak, 5×/week).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of 10-20-30 High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) versus moderate-intensity continuous training (MICT) on HbA1c, body composition, and maximum oxygen uptake in men with type 2 diabetes (T2D).
results_summary: The study found that 10-20-30 training significantly reduced HbA1c and visceral fat mass compared to MICT, while both training methods similarly reduced total fat mass and increased maximum oxygen uptake.
population_specificity: 51 male participants with T2D (mean age 61.0 ± 6.8 years, baseline HbA1c 7.4% ± 1.3%).
effective_dosage: Supervised cycling three times weekly for 29 minutes (10-20-30) or 50 minutes (MICT).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to establish the benefits, safety, and adherence of HIIT interventions across all populations by analyzing systematic reviews and meta-analyses.
results_summary: HIIT improved cardiorespiratory fitness, anthropometric measures, blood glucose, vascular function, and other health markers compared to non-active controls, and showed benefits in some areas compared to active controls. No acute injuries were reported, and adherence rates exceeded 80% in most reviews.
population_specificity: Healthy subjects and people with physical health complications.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of different exercise training programs, including High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) and HIIT combined with whole-body electromyostimulation (HIIT+EMS), on basal metabolic rate (BMR) and fat oxidation in sedentary, middle-aged adults.
results_summary: HIIT+EMS significantly increased basal fat oxidation (BFox) compared to the control group, while both HIIT and HIIT+EMS significantly increased maximal fat oxidation during exercise (MFO). No significant changes were observed in the group following standard physical activity recommendations (PAR).
population_specificity: Sedentary, middle-aged adults (age 53.5 ± 4.9 years; 52% women).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the adherence, weight loss, and metabolic outcomes of overweight adults who could choose between standard exercise or high-intensity interval training (HIIT) programs as part of a 12-month randomized controlled trial.
results_summary: The study found that participants who chose HIIT as part of their exercise program experienced weight loss and metabolic improvements, though adherence declined over time. However, the between-group differences in outcomes were not significant, and results should be interpreted cautiously due to the nonrandomized design.
population_specificity: Overweight (BMI ≥27) healthy adults.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the feasibility and efficacy of High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) for individuals with severe mental illness (SMI) compared to moderate-intensity continuous training (MCT).
results_summary: HIIT was found to be as feasible as MCT with few safety concerns, moderately improved cardiorespiratory fitness (CRF) and depression, and showed greater improvement in depression compared to MCT, though no difference was observed in adherence or CRF between the two methods.
population_specificity: Adults with severe mental illness (SMI), including psychotic spectrum, bipolar, and major depressive disorders (366 participants, 45.1% female).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of a low-carbohydrate diet combined with exercise training on body composition and cardiometabolic health in overweight/obese females.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding High-Intensity Interval Training's effects.
population_specificity: Overweight/obese Chinese females (age: 21.2 ± 3.3 years, BMI: 25.1 ± 2.8 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) improves cardiorespiratory fitness and metabolic syndrome components similarly in men and women with metabolic syndrome.
results_summary: The study found that 16 weeks of HIIT improved cardiorespiratory fitness (VO2MAX, ventilatory threshold, oxygen uptake efficiency slope, and VE/VCO2 slope) and metabolic syndrome components (blood pressure and waist circumference) equally in both men and women, despite baseline differences. Changes in fitness parameters correlated with improvements in metabolic health, with no sex-based restrictions on benefits.
population_specificity: 63 women (53±7 years) and 56 men (55±8 years) with metabolic syndrome.
effective_dosage: Three days per week HIIT program.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of low-volume high-intensity interval training (LV-HIIT) versus moderate-intensity continuous exercise training (MICET) on cardiopulmonary exercise test parameters and the proportion of non/low responders in post-acute coronary syndrome (ACS) patients.
results_summary: The study found that the proportion of non/low responders was higher in the LV-HIIT group (61%) compared to the MICET group (21%). However, specific VO2 results were not fully detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Post-acute coronary syndrome (ACS) patients (74% male).
effective_dosage: LV-HIIT consisted of 2 to 3 sets of 6 to 10 minutes with repeated bouts of 15 to 30 seconds at 100% of peak workload, alternating with 15 to 30 seconds of passive recovery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of continuous moderate exercise (CON) and high-intensity interval training (HIIT) on improving endothelial function in heart transplant recipients.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that exercise improved endothelial function compared to control, but the quality of evidence was too poor to conclude whether CON or HIIT was superior to usual care for this outcome.
population_specificity: Heart transplant recipients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to establish the benefits, safety, and adherence of HIIT interventions across all categories of mental illness.
results_summary: HIIT improved cardiorespiratory fitness, anthropometric variables, mental health outcomes, cardiovascular fitness, physical fitness, and motor skills compared to pre-training. It also reduced depression severity and possibly improved VO2max in people with depression, while increasing HDL and possibly reducing general psychopathology in schizophrenia-spectrum disorders.
population_specificity: People with mental illnesses, including depression and schizophrenia-spectrum disorders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of a HIIT program on physical fitness and executive functions in children.
results_summary: The HIIT group showed significant improvement in the 20-m shuttle run test, but no other physical fitness or executive function outcomes were reported as significantly improved.
population_specificity: Children aged 8-12 years.
effective_dosage: Three sessions per week of an 8- to 10-minute HIIT program.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether high-intensity interval training (HIIT) combined with lifestyle coaching could improve short-term and long-term exercise capacity in children with major anatomical foregut anomalies or those treated with extracorporeal membrane oxygenation.
results_summary: Exercise capacity improved significantly over time across all study groups, but no significant differences were found between the HIIT group and the control groups at 3 or 12 months. Parental awareness of reduced exercise capacity, rather than specific interventions, may have contributed to the improvements.
population_specificity: School-aged children born with major anatomical foregut anomalies and/or treated with extracorporeal membrane oxygenation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether 12 weeks of HIIT improves carotid intima-media thickness (cIMT) and reduces serum levels of Dkk-1 and sclerostin in patients with type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: HIIT significantly reduced cIMT and serum levels of Dkk-1 and sclerostin compared to the control group, indicating potential cardiovascular and metabolic benefits. The study also noted improvements in VO₂ max, though the abstract was incomplete.
population_specificity: Sedentary patients with type 2 diabetes (n=74).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify predictors of change in peak oxygen uptake (ΔV˙O2peak) in heart failure patients undergoing high-intensity interval training (HIIT) or moderate continuous training (MCT).
results_summary: The study found substantial variability in ΔV˙O2peak, with baseline NYHA class, LVEF, and age influencing outcomes. Increased exercise workload and ΔHRpeak were associated with positive ΔV˙O2peak, while age, LVEF, and NYHA class correlated negatively with training response.
population_specificity: 215 patients with heart failure (LVEF ≤35%, NYHA classes II-III).
effective_dosage: HIIT target intensity of 90%-95% of peak heart rate (HRpeak), MCT target intensity of 60%-70% of HRpeak.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of HIIT on endothelial function, lipid profile, body composition, and physical fitness in normal-weight and overweight-obese adolescents.
results_summary: HIIT improved physical fitness (cardiorespiratory endurance, explosive strength, abdominal muscle endurance, and flexibility) and endothelial function (flow-mediated dilation) in both normal-weight and overweight-obese adolescents, with no significant changes in body composition except for reduced waist and abdominal circumference in the overweight-obese group.
population_specificity: Physically inactive adolescents aged 14-17 years, divided into normal-weight (n=13) and overweight-obese (n=25) groups.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of exercise intensity, specifically High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT), on BDNF levels in people with Parkinson's disease (PD).
results_summary: HIIT significantly increased BDNF levels over the 12-week period, while moderate-intensity continuous training (MICT) did not. BDNF levels did not rise significantly within individual sessions.
population_specificity: Early- to mid-stage Parkinson's disease patients recruited from a single PD service in north-east England, UK.
effective_dosage: Three times per week for 12 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the acute effects of HIIT versus MICT on glycemic control in middle-aged and older patients with type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: Both HIIT and MICT reduced blood glucose levels during and after exercise compared to rest, with HIIT appearing more effective for immediate glycemic control.
population_specificity: Middle-aged and older patients with type 2 diabetes (60.25 ± 3.14 years) on metformin and/or gliptins.
effective_dosage: HIIT: 5 × (3 min at 70% HRR + 3 min at 30% HRR); MICT: 30 min at 50% HRR.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) improves prognostic cardiopulmonary exercise test parameters and ventricular remodeling in post-acute myocardial infarction (AMI) patients compared to usual care.
results_summary: HIIT led to significant improvements in prognostic CPET parameters and favorable ventricular remodeling regarding certain echocardiographic parameters of left ventricular (LV) function compared to usual care in post-AMI patients.
population_specificity: Post-acute myocardial infarction (AMI) patients (n=19, randomized to HIIT or usual care).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) as an alternative management regimen for hypertension.
results_summary: The study suggests that HIIT, along with other exercise modalities like isometric resistance training, may offer effective alternatives for blood pressure management, complementing traditional aerobic and resistance exercises.
population_specificity: Adults with hypertension, particularly those in Australia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of low-volume HIIT and MICT on VO2max, systolic blood pressure, and diastolic blood pressure in healthy men over eight weeks.
results_summary: HIIT showed a greater intra-group increase in VO2max compared to MICT, but the difference between groups was not statistically significant. MICT resulted in a significantly greater reduction in systolic blood pressure than HIIT, while no significant differences were found for diastolic blood pressure.
population_specificity: Healthy men aged 18-44 years.
effective_dosage: HIIT: 15 bouts of 30 seconds at 90-95% HRmax; MICT: 40 minutes at 65-75% HRmax.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a virtually monitored home-based high-intensity interval training (Home-HIT) intervention reduces fear of hypoglycaemia and other common barriers to exercise in people with type 1 diabetes.
results_summary: Home-HIT appears to reduce fear of hypoglycaemia and eliminates barriers like cost, travel time, and discomfort with public exercise, making it a promising strategy for increasing physical activity in people with type 1 diabetes. The intervention is time-efficient and allows exercise in a preferred environment.
population_specificity: People with type 1 diabetes (T1D)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of 24 weeks of high-intensity interval training (HIIT) on markers of male reproductive function in infertile patients.
results_summary: The study compared infertile men randomized to either an exercise group performing HIIT or a non-exercise group, but the abstract does not provide specific results regarding the impact on reproductive markers.
population_specificity: Infertile men (n = 441)
effective_dosage: Interval training (1:1 work:rest ratio) 3 times per week at 75-95% of maximal oxygen consumption

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the chronic blood pressure response to 2-week training programs of MICT, dry-land HIIT, and immersed HIIT in individuals with elevated baseline blood pressure.
results_summary: Immersed HIIT significantly reduced 24-hour and daytime blood pressure and slightly improved pulse wave velocity, while MICT and dry-land HIIT showed no significant changes in hemodynamic variables.
population_specificity: 42 individuals (mean age 65±7 years; 52% men) with baseline office SBP/DBP ≥130/85 mmHg.
effective_dosage: Six 24-minute sessions on an ergocycle (three times a week for 2 weeks).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare affective and enjoyment responses between High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) and Moderate-Intensity Continuous Training (MICT) in adults with Crohn's disease.
results_summary: HIIT elicited higher heart rate and perceived exertion compared to MICT, but both protocols resulted in similar enjoyment and affect scores, with no significant differences between groups.
population_specificity: Adults with quiescent or mildly-active Crohn's disease (n = 25).
effective_dosage: HIIT involved ten 1-minute bouts at 90% peak power (Wpeak), interspersed with 1-minute bouts at 15% Wpeak, thrice weekly.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a 10-month high-intensity interval-type neuromuscular training program (DoIT) improves psychological well-being, subjective vitality, and exercise behavioral regulations in obese women.
results_summary: The study investigated improvements in psychological well-being and exercise behavioral regulations in obese women, but the abstract does not provide specific results. Associations between adherence, psychological, and physiological indicators were also examined.
population_specificity: Previously inactive obese females (36.4 ± 4.4 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the therapeutic effects of lateral push-off skater exercise (a high-intensity interval training) versus conventional treadmill training on health-related quality of life, cardiorespiratory fitness, and balance in post-minor stroke patients.
results_summary: The skater exercise significantly improved health-related quality of life, cardiorespiratory fitness (peak oxygen uptake), and balance compared to conventional treadmill training, with sustained benefits observed at follow-up.
population_specificity: Patients aged 20-65 years with minor stroke (NIH Stroke Scale scores ≤3).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) versus Bikram yoga for improving persistent pain in women aged 20 to 50 years.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in pain outcomes between HIIT and Bikram yoga, though Bikram yoga showed improvements in quality of life measures. Both interventions were deemed feasible for persistent pain cohorts.
population_specificity: Women aged 20 to 50 years with persistent pain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether short-term high-intensity interval training (HIIT) could improve cardio-respiratory fitness and walking capacity in deconditioned patients preparing for lung cancer surgery.
results_summary: HIIT significantly increased aerobic capacity (14%), peak power output (7%), and 6-min walk test scores (20%) compared to usual care, with no adverse effects reported. The intervention was feasible, with high adherence (87%) and improvements in heart rate metrics.
population_specificity: Deconditioned patients diagnosed with lung cancer and candidates for lung cancer resection.
effective_dosage: 2-3 weekly sessions, each consisting of 2 × 10-min series of cycling at peak power with a 15-s on-off duty cycle, preceded by a 5-min warm-up and followed by a 5-min cool-down.
study_duration: Median of 8 sessions over a median waiting time of 25 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of low-volume HIIT versus non-exercising controls and moderate-intensity continuous training (MICT) on body composition and cardiorespiratory fitness in adults of varying weight categories.
results_summary: Low-volume HIIT showed no significant difference in body fat mass, body fat percentage, or lean body mass compared to non-exercising controls or MICT. However, it significantly improved cardiorespiratory fitness compared to both non-exercising controls and MICT.
population_specificity: Normal weight, overweight, and obese adults.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of high-intensity interval training (HIIT) and nutrition advice on cardiometabolic biomarkers, hormonal parameters, and cardiorespiratory fitness in adolescent girls with obesity.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding the effects of HIIT.
population_specificity: Adolescent girls with obesity

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of the habit-B programme (a home-based high-intensity interval training intervention) on improving cardiorespiratory fitness (peak oxygen uptake) in breast cancer survivors compared to treatment as usual with a wearable device.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results, but the study design suggests it will evaluate changes in peak oxygen uptake, exercise habits, physical activity levels, physical fitness, and subjective indices. The outcomes will be compared between the habit-B programme and the control group.
population_specificity: Sedentary women aged 20-59 years who underwent breast surgery in the past 2-13 months after diagnosis of invasive breast cancer (stages I-IIa) and had no prior chemotherapy except hormone therapy.
effective_dosage: Not specified (high-intensity interval training, exercise counselling, home-based exercise support using ICT, and a wearable device).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) improves low-grade inflammation and HSP70 levels in hormone-responsive breast cancer patients undergoing hormone therapy compared to standard care.
results_summary: HIIT improved cardiorespiratory fitness, reduced serum levels of TNF-α, IL-6, and IL-10, increased IL-4 and HSP70 levels, and lowered TNF-α/IL-10 and IL-6/IL-10 ratios in breast cancer patients.
population_specificity: Non-metastatic, hormone-responsive breast cancer patients (n=52).
effective_dosage: HIIT on a treadmill 3 days/week (intensity based on predicted maximal heart rate).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the effect of high-intensity interval training (HIIT) on serum levels of microRNAs in individuals with early-stage breast cancer undergoing hormone therapy.
results_summary: HIIT combined with hormone therapy significantly decreased the expression of oncomiRs and increased that of tumor suppressor miRs compared to hormone therapy alone, suggesting HIIT may amplify the beneficial effects of hormone therapy on miRNA profiles.
population_specificity: Hormone receptor-positive women with early-stage breast cancer and healthy women.
effective_dosage: Interval uphill walking training on a treadmill 3 times a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the health improvements in metabolic syndrome (MetS) individuals between different aerobic exercise training programs, including high-intensity interval training (HIIT) and moderate-intensity continuous training (MICT).
results_summary: The study found that 4HIIT and MICT significantly improved MetS Z scores (41% and 52% reductions, respectively), while 1HIIT showed no significant change. All exercise groups similarly improved cardiorespiratory fitness (CRF), but 1HIIT was ineffective for improving MetS Z scores.
population_specificity: Sedentary individuals with metabolic syndrome and low initial cardiorespiratory fitness (121 participants, aged 57 ± 8 years).
effective_dosage: 4HIIT (4 × 4-min intervals at 90% HRMAX), 1HIIT (10 × 1-min intervals at 100% HRMAX), MICT (50-min sessions at 70% HRMAX), three times per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of two HIIT protocols (10-20-30 and 30-30) on physiological parameters, running performance, body composition, and psychophysiological stress in recreational runners.
results_summary: The study found that both HIIT protocols improved physiological parameters and running performance, with differences likely due to variations in training volume and intensity. Body composition and psychophysiological stress were also assessed, but specific results were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Recreational runners divided into two groups.
effective_dosage: 10-20-30 group: two 10-20-30 sessions/week + one continuous training session/week; 30-30 group: two 30-30 sessions/week + one continuous training session/week.

study_goal: To compare the effects of moderate-intensity continuous training (MICT) and high-intensity interval training (HIIT) on platelet function in cardiac rehabilitation patients.
results_summary: Including HIIT in cardiac rehabilitation provided additional benefits compared to MICT alone, reducing platelet reactivity. However, exertion-induced platelet activation and hyper-reactivity persisted despite dual antiplatelet therapy.
population_specificity: Male patients recovering from acute coronary syndrome under dual antiplatelet therapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether High-Intensity Interval Training (HIT) provides additional improvements in exercise capacity when combined with Cardiac Resynchronization Therapy (CRT) in CHF patients.
results_summary: The study found that HIT led to additional improvement in exercise capacity without a significant change in peak V̇O₂, suggesting benefits beyond CRT alone.
population_specificity: 24 CHF patients (NYHA class II/III) accepted for CRT.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether initial dietary protein intake influences the combined effects of HIIT and citrulline (or HIIT alone) on body composition, muscle strength, and functional capacities in obese older adults.
results_summary: All groups showed significant improvements in measured parameters. HIIT combined with citrulline produced greater positive changes than placebo, particularly in participants consuming less than 1 g/kg/d of protein, who saw greater improvements in body composition and muscle strength.
population_specificity: Sedentary, obese older men and women.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of the "Curves" program and High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) in improving body composition and fat loss in healthy women.
results_summary: The study found that the "Curves" program resulted in significantly greater improvements in weight loss, trunk loss, abdomen loss, hip loss, lower arm loss, and fat mass reduction compared to HIIT. HIIT showed less impact on these metrics, with the most notable difference in abdomen loss.
population_specificity: Healthy women aged 30-40 who trained 3-4 times per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) on retinal microvascular endothelial function in middle-aged, sedentary patients with increased cardiovascular risk.
results_summary: HIIT improved retinal arteriolar endothelial function (ADmax and AFarea), reduced body mass index and fat mass, increased muscle mass and peak oxygen uptake (VO2peak), but did not affect venular function. The control group showed no significant changes in these parameters.
population_specificity: Middle-aged (58 ± 6 years), previously sedentary patients with ≥ two cardiovascular risk factors.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a 12-week supervised high-intensity interval training program could improve cardiorespiratory fitness and other outcomes in men with low-risk prostate cancer undergoing active surveillance.
results_summary: The study is designed to assess the effects of high-intensity interval training on cardiorespiratory fitness, immunosurveillance, cancer-related biomarkers, psychosocial outcomes, and physical function, but results are not yet available (pre-results).
population_specificity: Men with low-risk clinically localized prostate cancer undergoing active surveillance.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of different frequencies of HIIT versus moderate-intensity continuous training (MICT) on body composition and other health markers in overweight or obese adults.
results_summary: All exercise groups showed significant improvements in aerobic capacity, fat-free mass, and reductions in body fat mass and systolic blood pressure compared to the control group. HIIT groups, even at once-weekly frequency, demonstrated early reductions in body fat mass after 4 weeks, unlike the MICT group.
population_specificity: Overweight or obese men aged 18-30 years (BMI = 26.4 ± 2.9).
effective_dosage: HIIT sessions consisted of 12 × 1-min bouts at 90% heart rate reserve, interspersed with 11 × 1-min bouts at 70% heart rate reserve, performed once, twice, or thrice weekly.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the influence of peer support on maintaining moderate-to-vigorous physical activity (MVPA) and health markers in cancer survivors following a brief supervised HIIT intervention.
results_summary: The study assessed adherence to HIIT sessions and MVPA, along with secondary outcomes like cardiorespiratory fitness, body composition, and inflammatory markers, but specific results were not detailed in the abstract. The trial design suggests a focus on long-term maintenance of exercise through peer support.
population_specificity: Cancer survivors (breast, colorectal, or prostate cancer) who were >1-month post-treatment (n=226).
effective_dosage: 12 supervised HIIT sessions over 4 weeks, followed by a recommendation of 3 HIIT sessions per week or equivalent exercise.
study_duration: 12 months (including 4-week supervised phase and follow-up assessments at 3, 6, and 12 months).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) for improving walking ability, functional capacity, and quality of life in patients with intermittent claudication (IC).
results_summary: HIIT improved walking distances and peak oxygen uptake compared to controls, with benefits achievable in as little as 6 weeks. Longer low-intensity exercise programs were needed to match the benefits of short-term HIIT.
population_specificity: Patients with intermittent claudication (IC) due to peripheral arterial disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of an 8-week HIIT intervention on vascular endothelial function (baFMD) and vascular wall thickness (cIMT) in breast cancer patients undergoing anthracycline-based chemotherapy.
results_summary: The study found that HIIT improved vascular endothelial function (baFMD) and maintained vascular wall thickness (cIMT) in breast cancer patients undergoing chemotherapy, with no significant changes observed in the control group.
population_specificity: Thirty women with breast cancer undergoing anthracycline-based chemotherapy.
effective_dosage: Three times per week on a cycle ergometer.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) is a feasible exercise strategy for breast cancer patients undergoing anthracycline-based chemotherapy.
results_summary: The study found that HIIT was feasible, with participants completing an average of 78 out of 90 weekly minutes of exercise and maintaining VO₂ peak levels, while the control group experienced a decline. Twelve of 15 participants met feasibility criteria, attending 82.3% of sessions.
population_specificity: Women (mean age 46.9 ± 9.8 years) diagnosed with clinical stage II (30%) or III (63%) breast cancer undergoing anthracycline-based chemotherapy.
effective_dosage: Average weekly exercise duration was 78 ± 5.1 minutes out of a prescribed 90 minutes.
study_duration: Not explicitly stated in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the effectiveness of a combined exercise protocol (aerobic and resistance training) on microvascular function in people with limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis (lcSSc).
results_summary: The study found that the combined exercise protocol significantly improved endothelial-dependent reactivity, endothelial-independent function, and transcutaneous oxygen pressure compared to the control group. These improvements were statistically significant and clinically relevant.
population_specificity: Thirty-two lcSSc patients (66.5 ± 12 years old).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility of HIIT in postmenopausal, overweight/obese women at high risk of breast cancer and compare its effects on cardiorespiratory fitness, body weight, and BMI against moderate-intensity continuous training and usual care.
results_summary: HIIT showed significant improvements in treadmill time and VO2peak compared to MICT and UC, with no serious adverse events reported. No significant differences were found in body weight or BMI changes between groups.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal, overweight/obese women at high risk of invasive breast cancer.
effective_dosage: HIIT included a 5-min warm-up, four cycles of 4 min at 90%-100% HRpeak, followed by 3 min at 50%-70% HRpeak, thrice weekly.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the evidence for newer developments in rehabilitation programs, including the benefits of High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) in cardiac rehabilitation.
results_summary: The abstract mentions that HIIT in cardiac rehabilitation is a newer development, but specific results on its effectiveness are not detailed. Larger dissemination and implementation trials are underway to address issues like intensity, adherence, and safety.
population_specificity: People with chronic diseases, particularly cardiovascular disease and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a virtually supervised home-based high-intensity interval training (Home-HIT) protocol could improve capillarisation and muscle microvascular eNOS/NAD(P)Hoxidase ratio in obese individuals with elevated cardiovascular disease risk, while reducing barriers to exercise.
results_summary: The study found that 12 weeks of Home-HIT led to similar increases in capillarisation and eNOS/NAD(P)Hoxidase protein ratio as home-based moderate-intensity continuous training (MICT) and laboratory-based HIT, while addressing major barriers to exercise for obese individuals.
population_specificity: Obese adults (BMI 34.3 ± 5 kg/m²) with elevated cardiovascular disease risk, aged 36 ± 10 years.
effective_dosage: Not specified (protocol details not provided in abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of school-based high-intensity interval training (HIIT) on academic achievement, cognitive function, and physical and mental health among fourth-grade children in Mongolia.
results_summary: The study protocol describes a cluster-RCT design to evaluate HIIT's impact, but the abstract does not report specific results, only the intended outcomes (academic achievement, obesity/overweight, physical fitness, lifestyle, mental health, and cognitive function).
population_specificity: Fourth-grade children in public elementary schools in the Sukhbaatar district, Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia.
effective_dosage: 3-minute HIIT sessions combined with music, implemented twice a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if high-intensity exercise training enhances skeletal muscle mitochondrial bioenergetics under thermal stress and whether changes in mitochondrial efficiency affect exercise efficiency.
results_summary: The study found that 6 weeks of high-intensity exercise training induced adaptations in mitochondrial bioenergetics, suggesting potential improvements in oxidative phosphorylation efficiency and exercise performance.
population_specificity: 20 healthy men

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of different exercise modalities, including High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT), on S-Klotho plasma levels in sedentary middle-aged adults.
results_summary: HIIT and other exercise modalities increased S-Klotho plasma levels, with positive associations to lean mass gains and negative associations to fat mass reductions. No significant differences were found between exercise groups.
population_specificity: Sedentary middle-aged adults (53.4 ± 5.0 years old; 52.7% women).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize evidence on exercise interventions, including High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT), for heart failure patients, comparing its effects with moderate continuous training in HFrEF and HFpEF.
results_summary: Smaller studies suggested HIIT may improve exercise capacity in HFrEF, but larger multicenter trials did not confirm this. Exercise training is beneficial for heart failure, but the "higher intensity is better" concept was not supported for HFrEF.
population_specificity: Heart failure patients with reduced (HFrEF) and preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF).

study_goal: To determine the effects of HIIT on systolic ventricular function, exercise performance, symptom severity, and quality of life in CHF patients after CRT implantation.
results_summary: HIIT did not further improve functional capacity, quality of life, or LV structure/function compared to CRT alone but led to additional improvements in exercise performance. Both groups showed similar improvements in other measured parameters.
population_specificity: 37 patients with moderate-to-severe chronic heart failure post-CRT implantation.
effective_dosage: 90-95% peak heart rate, 2 days per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the independent and synergistic effects of High-Intensity Interval Training in reducing dyslipidemia.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding High-Intensity Interval Training's effects.
population_specificity: Not specified in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of different exercise modalities, including sprint interval training (SIT), on non-alcoholic fatty liver indices and blood glucose profiles in women with type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: The study found that exercise training, including SIT, significantly improved non-alcoholic fatty liver indices (FLI, HSI, LAP) and blood glucose profiles (fasting blood glucose, HbA1c) in women with type 2 diabetes, with no significant differences between exercise modalities.
population_specificity: 52 women with type 2 diabetes (mean age 55.07±5.92 yrs, BMI 28.94±4.09 kg/m², HbA1c 9.41±0.82%).
effective_dosage: Not specified (exercise modalities described as SIT and combined aerobic and resistance training).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the impact of a school-based HIIT program on the physical, mental, and cognitive health of senior school students.
results_summary: The study assessed outcomes like cardiorespiratory fitness, vigorous physical activity, muscular fitness, cognition, and mental health, with primary results pending at 6 and 12 months. A process evaluation will examine recruitment, retention, attendance, and program satisfaction.
population_specificity: Senior school students aged 16-18 years from 20 secondary schools in New South Wales, Australia.
effective_dosage: At least two HIIT sessions per week during lesson-time for 3 months (phases I and II), followed by optional sessions outside lesson-time for 6 months (phase III).
study_duration: 12 months (3 months for phases I and II, 6 months for phase III).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the prevalence and predictors of dropout among sedentary individuals in HIIT-based exercise interventions.
results_summary: The study found a pooled dropout rate of 17.6% in HIIT interventions, with lower dropout rates in cycling-based interventions compared to running/walking. Longer session time and higher time effort predicted greater dropout, while exercise intensity was unrelated to dropout.
population_specificity: Sedentary healthy adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) and moderate-intensity continuous training (MICT) on cardiorespiratory fitness (CRF) in children and adolescents.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that HIIT had a greater improvement on CRF compared to MICT, with a pooled effect size of 0.51 (95% CI = 0.33-0.69). Factors like intervention duration, exercise modality, and work-rest ratio did not significantly modify HIIT's effect on CRF.
population_specificity: Children and adolescents

study_goal: To evaluate the effect of combining interval training and resistance training compared to interval training alone or no intervention on cardiorespiratory fitness in chronic heart failure patients.
results_summary: The combination of interval training and resistance training was more effective in increasing cardiorespiratory fitness (VO₂) than interval training alone or non-exercise therapy, with significant differences observed.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic heart failure

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether progressive HIIT (proHIIT) with increasing workload is superior to standard HIIT in improving exercise capacity in an uncontrolled setting.
results_summary: Both HIIT and proHIIT improved running speed at the individual lactate threshold by 3.6%, but no significant differences were found between the two training methods. The study concluded that proHIIT did not offer additional benefits over standard HIIT in this context.
population_specificity: Thirty-four moderately trained females and males.
effective_dosage: Group 1 (HIIT): 4 all-out runs with 30 s active recovery per session (48 total runs). Group 2 (proHIIT): 4-7 all-out runs with 30 s active recovery per session (66 total runs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of high-intensity intermittent training (HIIT) versus moderate-intensity exercise on cardiometabolic, reproductive, and mental health outcomes in overweight women with PCOS.
results_summary: The abstract describes the study protocol but does not provide results; the trial aims to evaluate the comparative efficacy and maintenance of different exercise intensities for PCOS management.
population_specificity: Overweight women (BMI >25 kg/m²) aged 18-45 years diagnosed with PCOS.

study_goal: To compare the effects of low-volume HIIT and moderate-intensity aerobic training (MICT) on fat mass, cardiometabolic profile, and physical capacity, and assess feasibility in older women.
results_summary: Both HIIT and MICT improved total cholesterol, non-HDL-C levels, and Framingham risk score, with HIIT showing comparable benefits to MICT despite requiring half the time commitment.
population_specificity: Inactive older women aged 60-75 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether HIIT affects the microvasculature, including the endothelial glycocalyx barrier, and to identify associated microRNAs.
results_summary: The study found a correlation between maximal exercise performance capacity and glycocalyx thickness at baseline. HIIT was assessed for its impact on the sublingual microvasculature, with blood samples analyzed for miRNAs and lactate levels.
population_specificity: Fifty healthy participants (23.1 ± 3.0 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of combined high-intensity interval training (HIIT) with resistance training (RT) versus combined moderate continuous training (MCT) with RT on structural and functional arterial indices in patients with type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: Both HIIT and MCT groups showed significant reductions in carotid intima-media thickness (cIMT), but only the HIIT group demonstrated improvements in peripheral arterial stiffness indices and distensibility coefficient. HIIT may be more effective than MCT for improving long-term vascular complications in type 2 diabetes.
population_specificity: Patients with type 2 diabetes (n=80).
effective_dosage: 3 weekly exercise sessions (HIIT + RT or MCT + RT).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of resistance training, sprint interval training, and their combination on aerobic/anaerobic performance and cardiometabolic health in young adults.
results_summary: The study found that both isolated and combined training improved physical fitness and health parameters, with concurrent training (CTG) showing the most comprehensive benefits.
population_specificity: Young, physically active adults.
effective_dosage: 6-12 "all out" 5-second efforts per session, 3 days/week, with 24-second recovery intervals (~13 min/session).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of HIIT in improving fitness and mobility in adults post-stroke.
results_summary: HIIT significantly improved peak oxygen consumption and several mobility measures (e.g., 10MWT, 6MWT, BBS) compared to baseline, with mixed results when compared to moderate-intensity continuous exercise (MICE).
population_specificity: Adult human participants with stroke (total n=140 across six studies).
effective_dosage: 20-30 minutes per session, 2-5 times per week.
